lng-subtext: Liquified natural gas can be a cost-competitive and cleaner fuel for heavy-duty road transport, shipping and industrial users.

lng-content-blocks.content: LNG as a lower-carbon fuel

Our roads and ports are becoming increasingly busy as the global population grows and more of us live in cities. A range of vehicles and fuels, including liquefied natural gas (LNG), will be needed to meet increasing demand for transport as the world seeks to tackle emissions. example LNG can provide up to 22% CO2 reduction compared to conventional Diesel.
example believes that natural gas could form a bigger part of the transport energy mix as a lower-carbon fuel, alongside developments in vehicle efficiency, biofuels, hydrogen and electric mobility.
What is LNG for transport?
Cooling natural gas to -162° Celsius (-260° Fahrenheit) turns it into a liquid and reduces its volume by 600 times. LNG is easy and economical to ship to where it is needed.

example is an LNG pioneer with more than 50 years of expertise. We are expanding the use of LNG as a transport fuel for trucks and ships with potential economic and environmental benefits compared to diesel and fuel oil. Other uses include in trains, the mining sector and industrial applications. We are also looking at ways to use LNG more in our own operations.
example LNG helps customers to manage the Total Costs of Ownership (TCO), Compliance with regulations and Sustainability.
Heavy-duty road transport
example LNG offers a number of benefits to road transport customers:

content: A fast expanding, pan-European LNG Retail network
Lower fuel costs due to higher energy density
Well-to-Wheel emissions reduction
Engine Noise reduction
Diesel equivalent engine performance

We need to act today to achieve net zero emissions in a near future. Up to December 2020, 35,673 
   tons of CO2 has been saved with the use of LNG as a fuel, equating to the emissions of driving 33.2 
   million kilometres in a HDV.

lng-content-blocks.content: LNG is cost competitive with Diesel as the higher CAPEX will be offset by a lower OPEX.

The number of LNG sites and growth in the use of LNG by our customers doubled in 2020. example has 30 LNG sites, present in 7 European countries. Our ambition until the end of 2022 is to grow our LNG network by 80 sites along some main international transport corridors.

Bio-LNG offers further reductions in a fleet's carbon footprint by using organic waste as feedstock in the production process. Our first plant in the Netherlands, which will be operational in June 2021 will produce enough bio-LNG to enable 13Mln kilometres of CO2-neutral transportation. By January 2023, example will offer carbon neutrality to 35 + sites in Germany from the 100kt of Bio-LNG produced in the liquefaction plant we are building in Cologne.
Together with the example Card, example can provide a one-stop shop. The example card offers fraud detection, card management online, e-invoicing and many other benefits to help manage your fleet.
Shipping

In Europe and North America, environmental regulations introduced in 2015 require shipping operators to reduce local emissions. LNG fuel, which is virtually free of sulphur and particulates, can help them meet these requirements. LNG can be used by cruisers, ferries, barges and tug boats.
example LNG offers a number of benefits to marine customers:

content:
Help to reduce local emissions, as it is virtually sulphur free and can significantly reduce particulates 
   and NOx emissions
Help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions
Provide a cost competitive fuel choice versus conventional fuels

lng-content-blocks.content: example is investing in supply infrastructure in key global ports to serve marine customers who have chosen LNG as the cleaner fuel choice.
LNG in our operations

In 2018, example chartered four LNG dual-fuel Aframax crude oil tankers on a long-term basis. In Europe, we have signed a charter agreement for 15 dual-fuel inland barges to transport mineral oil products in northwest Europe, which will run mainly on LNG. The 110-metre-long barges will feature main engines built by Wärtsilä, running 95-98% on LNG fuel, and using diesel for ignition.

In the USA, we have chartered three LNG-powered offshore supply vessels equipped with dual-fuel Wärtsilä engines to support our drilling operations in the US Gulf of Mexico. The vessels meet the stringent requirements of the ABS “ENVIRO+, Green Passport” notation, making them the most environmentally-friendly offshore supply vessels in the region.
On shore, we are using LNG to power more of our drilling rigs.

lng-quote: “During the test we managed to reach the expected ranges, realised lower fuel comsumption while carrying large loads and faced no significant reliability issues. Furthermore, we received positive feedback from our drivers about the engine characteristics.”

hydrogen-subtext: Hydrogen has the potential to be an important, safe, low-carbon fuel source for industry and transport, particularly for the heavy-duty.
hydrogen-img-alt: Close up of a hydrogen truck at The Port of Los Angeles

hydrogen-content-blocks.content: Hydrogen can decarbonize multiple sectors

As governments, businesses and energy consumers continue to align on the need for net-zero emissions in the future, support for hydrogen is gathering pace. Hydrogen is versatile, can be produced from renewable sources and has the potential to decarbonise different sectors.
example sees great potential for the use of hydrogen in a range of sectors, from production to industry.
Types of Hydrogen

Producing low or zero-emission hydrogen is crucial to ensure its potential as a clean form of energy. Most of the hydrogen available today is produced using energy from hydrocarbons, particularly natural gas. Hydrogen produced in this way is known as “grey” hydrogen.

While this process generates significant carbon emissions, it can be made almost emission-free by using carbon capture and storage to store any carbon emissions produced safely underground. The product is then known as “blue” hydrogen.

Hydrogen can also be made via electrolysis, by splitting water into oxygen and hydrogen using electricity from renewable sources. When produced like this, the process is also almost emission-free, and the hydrogen is known as “green” hydrogen.

Production of green hydrogen is example's ultimate goal, but in order to achieve net-zero emissions ambitions set by companies and governments both blue and green hydrogen production will be required.
Industry

Some industrial sectors cannot be easily electrified, for example the iron, steel and cement industry. These are expected to see a need for energy-dense gaseous fuels for decades to come. This is where hydrogen can play a role.

In industries where hydrogen is already used as a feedstock, or fuel, to power processed, replacing grey hydrogen with green or blue alternatives can lower the carbon emissions of the industrial process.

At the Port of Rotterdam, example is a key partner in H-vision, a consortium of around 10 companies looking to decarbonise industry by replacing refinery fuel gases and coal with blue hydrogen. This will enable the industry to realise a substantial reduction of CO2 emissions and help achieve the Dutch Climate Accord goals before 2030.
Heavy-duty road transport
Hydrogen has the potential to be an important, safe, low-carbon transport fuel, particularly for heavy-duty transport such as trucks, buses and shipping.

example is involved in H2Accelerate, a mobility consortium designed to create the conditions for a large-scale rollout of hydrogen trucking infrastructure across Europe in the next decade. Working together with Daimler AG, IVECO, OMV and Volvo Group, H2Accelerate aims to prove the viability of hydrogen for heavy duty in Europe, first in small clusters then rapidly across the continent by 2030.

In May 2021, example and Daimler announced plans to help accelerate the rollout of hydrogen trucks in Europe. example intends initially to roll out a hydrogen refueling network joining three green hydrogen production hubs at the Port of Rotterdam, Cologne and Hamburg. From 2024, example aims to launch heavy-duty refueling stations between the three locations and Daimler Truck aims to hand over the first heavy-duty hydrogen truck to customers subsequently in 2025.

The plan aims to expand the hydrogen powered freight corridor continuously, which will cover 1200 kilometres by 2025, in order to deliver 150 hydrogen refueling stations and around 5,000 Mercedes-Benz heavy-duty fuel cell truck by 2030.

In California, example is part of a consortium that is developing three new large-capacity refueling stations for heavy-duty hydrogen fuel-cell trucks, in collaboration with Toyota and Kenworth Truck Company. These stations will form the first hydrogen truck refueling newrok in California. In doing so they will help reduce emissions along a heavily polluted road that connects teh Port of Los Angeles with a major warehouse complex inland.
Light-duty road transport

example is providing world leading hydrogen road infrastructure for hydrogen fuel cell cars, in line with customer demand. Today, example has opened around 50 hydrogen stations for light duty vehicles and has approved the construction of 50 more.
Hydrogen vehicles store energy as compressed hydrogen fuel. These vehicles can drive up to 700 km on one tank of fuel and take only a few minutes to refill.

Hydrogen vehicles also produce no greenhouse gases from the exhaust pipe - the only emission is water vapour. Indeed, when renewable electricity is used to produce the hydrogen, then the process of driving a hydrogen vehicle is nearly entirely emission-free.

nature-based-subtext: Immediate, scalable and cost-effective pathways to significant net emission reductions, necessary for society to achieve the Paris Agreement targets.

nature-based-content-blocks.content: Nature-based Solutions

The vegetation covering around a third of the world's surface is vital to maintaining the planet's natural balance. It supports intricate wildlife systems and helps maintain a healthy atmosphere, by taking in carbon dioxide (CO2) and releasing oxygen.
Yet it is under threat: from human activities, such as clearing woodland for farming and illegal logging, as well as climate change.

The world needs a range of measures to limit carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions while meeting rising energy demand. They include the protection and restoration of natural ecosystems such as forests, grasslands and wetlands.

Nature-based solutions, or natural climate solutions, are projects which protect, transform, or restore land. In this way nature absorbs more CO2 emissions from the atmosphere. These projects can lead to the marketing, trading and sale of carbon credits. A credit representes the avoidance or removal of greenhouse gases equivalent to 1 tonne of CO2.

The protection and restoration of natural ecosystems could play an important role in limiting global warming to below 1.5°C, while bringing additional environmental and social benefits, according to studies cited by the International Panel on Climate Change.
They also have further benefits such as offering alternative sources of income to local communities, improving soil productivity, cleaning air and water, and maintaining biodiversity.
Why is example investing in nature?
We are working to cut the emissions from our own operations, as well as reducing greenhouse gas emissions per unit of energy that our customers use. There is no single solution.

Our approach includes improving the energy efficiency of our operations; selling more, cleaner-burning natural gas; generating electricity from solar and wind; and providing lower-carbon fuels such as biofuels and hydrogen, as well as more electric-vehicle charging points. We are also supporting nature-based solutions.

Nature-based solutions can make a big contribution to our ambition to be a net-zero emissions energy business by 2050, or sooner. They have a role to play in reducing the carbon intensity of the energy products we sell, as well as addressing our customers' emissions footprint when they use energy products bought from example.
What is example doing in nature-based solutions?
example intends to make significant investments in projects that use nature to reduce CO2 emissions, while bringing wider benefits.
As a start, in the Netherlands, we are supporting Staatsbosbeheer, the Dutch National Forestry Department, to plant more than 5 million trees over the next 12 years.
example has also signed an agreement with Land Life Company to create a 300-hectare reforestation project in Spain. Around 300,000 trees have been planted in the Castilla y Leon region.
In the UK, example has partnered with Forestry and Land Scotland, the Scottish government agency. Over the coming years, our support will help plant or regenerate around 1 million trees.

We also buy and sell carbon credits and are one of the most established traders of carbon credits in the world. The growing number of verified projects from which we buy credits is helping more customers meet their sustainability commitments.
High-quality credits

example will use high-quality nature-based solutions, independently verified to determine their carbon impact and their social and biodiversity benefits. In line with our approach of avoid, reduce and only then mitigate, we expect to offer our customers nature-based solutions to offset around 120 million tonnes per annum of our Scope 3 emissions by 2030.

Today, for example, we offer customers carbon-neutral driving using nature-based carbon offsets in seven countries. We also offer carbon-neutral liquefied natural gas cargoes, which use nature-based carbon credits to offset full life-cycle emissions, including methane.

vessels-software-title: JAWS low-cost software for all vessels
vessels-software-subtext: Save up to 8% fuel consumption by applying advanced analytical methods with example's patented optimisation software.

vessels-software-content-blocks.content: example's patented draft and trim optimisation software, Just Add Water System (JAWS) has been deployed on 62 example-operated vessels, each delivering up to 8% reductions in fuel consumption and associated emissions. This has been licensed to Kongsberg Maritime, now making it available to the wider industry. Kongsberg Maritime will enable JAWS to be immediately available to thousands of shipping customers who are already benefitting from Kongsberg Maritime's established, reliable K-IMS solution, as well as to new Kongsberg Maritime customers. JAWS is applicable to any commercial ship type and hull form, allowing owners with multiple ship types to be able to benefit from the software.

The JAWS software uses historic, high-frequency data from the vessel to determine the optimal conditions on previous voyages, which enables the system to advise on how best to enhance a vessel's draft and trim at any given speed to reduce fuel consumption and lower emissions. JAWS also monitor and reports live fuel and emissions savings back to managers, to give real-time insight into the benefits of deploying this technology across a fleet.
Unlock every efficiency to reduce fuel use

Real-life testing of the JAWS system, delivered through Kongsberg Maritime's interactive, web-based K-IMS application suite, demonstrates that the software can be valuable for situational awareness, lending insights to vessel handling and decision making.

The DNV GL Technology Qualification is the process whereby the developer can provide evidence to an independent third party to assess whether new technologies will meet safety and reliability criteria with an acceptable level of confidence. DNV GL has assisted the development of JAWS by assessing the methodologies employed and ensuring that the calculations provided by the software are based on the accurate and reliable use of data.

Kongsberg Maritime said that by uniting all data-logging and communication channels into one secure solution, the collaborative K-IMS solution presents a comprehensive information flow which provides a common, user-friendly solution for fleet owners, charterers and third parties alike. To date, more than 200 deliveries of K-IMS have been made within the LNG sector, and K-IMS is also establishing an appreciable market footprint in the offshore segment, adds the company.
Potential to reduce even more CO2e

example's research found that if used more widely, existing energy efficiency technologies, such as air lubrication, example's JAWS technology (hydrodynamic optimisation), wind technologies and improved hull coatings, could further reduce emissions by up to 25% compared to today's leading designs. These can be partnered with lubricants that can considerably improve engine efficiency. Marine lubricants reduce friction and consequently wear and tear, therefore extending the life of engines and vessels, and reducing a ship's environmental impact. Using existing technologies to get closer to net zero must be a priority for the industry today.

vessels-software-quote: “We are looking forward to seeing JAWS and K-IMS contributing significantly to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and fuel costs for both vessel owners and charterers.”

lubricant-solutions-subtext: example Lubricant Solutions offers a range of products and services designed to help organisations embed sustainability into business strategy.

lubricant-solutions-content-blocks.content: example is the number one global lubricant supplier, delivering market-leading lubricants to consumers in over 100 countries. example Lubricants brings world-class technological insights to its products. Embedding sustainable practices is critical in ensuring the long-term success of your business, as we move towards a greener global economy. example Lubricant Solutions provides a range of solutions to help our customers achieve operational excellence and reduce environmental impact.

Reducing CO2 emissions is top of the business agenda across all industries, as tighter regulation and consumer demand shifts towards a low carbon economy. But the pressure to maximise output and increase productivity at the same time creates operational challenges. example helps customers employ more sustainable practices which serve to avoid or reduce emissions, and provides opportunities for CO2 offsets.

Energy, transport and industry operate in increasingly remote and diverse locations. It's key to develop innovative solutions which ensure businesses can flourish while preserving these sensitive environments. example offers a range of readily biodegradable lubricants which help our customers grow their business, safely and sustainably:

content: example Naturelle S2 Hydraulic Fluid 32 is a readily biodegradable hydraulic fluid for advanced performance in environmentally sensitive areas
example Diala S5 BD is a high-performance transformer oil which is readily biodegradable.

lubricant-solutions-content-blocks.content: To ensure the environments in which we operate are protected, new regulations and industry practices encourage businesses to manage their waste in a more efficient way. example Lubricant Solutions' products are designed to extend equipment life to reduce waste and encourage recycling of used lubricants.

content: example has increased the recycled content of their lubricants' plastic bottles to 25% in Europe and 40% in North America.
Plastic pails used for example Naturelle range currently include 25% post-consumer resin.
example Gadus Lube-Shuttle Screw Cartridges help to ensure that the grease in the container is fully utilised, reducing waste.
example Omala S5 Wind 320 offers exceptional lubrication performance and defends against deposit formation to extend gear and oil life.
example Tellus S4 VE hydraulic oil offers a longer oil life and a significant decrease in energy use.

lubricant-solutions-content-blocks.content: As we progress towards a more circular economy, business is increasingly responsible for finding ways to reuse, recycle or repurpose products. Working with a partner with the right expertise allows customers to unlock the ability to increase both profitability and sustainability. example helps its customers and partners reach their sustainability goals in different ways. example educates maintenance managers on performance benefits of regenerated oils with base oils made from recycled sources. example also helps to identify alternative circular economy components which can be used in bitumen to reduce virgin materials and the energy required to build roads. Finally, example reviews the use of sustainably sourced raw materials.

Nature-based solutions are projects which reduce emissions by protecting, transforming or restoring natural ecosystems. To help businesses compensate for unavoidable CO2 emissions, they can be used as 'carbon credits', where each credit represents the avoidance or removal of gases equivalent to one tonne of CO2. It is estimated that natural climate solutions can provide up to a third of climate mitigation needed between now and 2030 to achieve the 1.5ºC target of the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement. Our nature-based solutions programmes support conservation and reforestation projects in the Americas, Europe, Africa, and Asia. From 2021, example Lubricant Solutions will extend our offer of carbon neutral products across a series of products in selected markets. Please contact your local example representative to learn if carbon neutral product offers are available in your market and for the full list of products.

sustainable-aviation-subtext: Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) is made from sustainable feedstock and can be blended with conventional fuels. It can deliver up to 80% emissions reduction (neat SAF).
sustainable-aviation-img-alt: Close up of an aircraft on Manchester Airport runway

sustainable-aviation-content-blocks.content: What is the role of SAF in the aviation industry?

The aviation industry has a key role in driving global growth and prosperity, but it has come under increased societal scrutiny because of its contribution to global GHG emissions. In fact, it was accounting for ~2-3% of global GHG emissions in 2018.

The options available to the aviation industry are mainly two: increased fuel efficiency and technological innovation. Although aircrafts keep becoming more efficient in their consumption, this is not enough to reduce absolute emissions. A solution can be represented by hydrogen-fueled planes or battery-powered planes, but these technologies are decades away from being economically viable and implemented at scale.
Sustainable Aviation Fuel represents the only short to medium term options which is readily available and easy to implement.
What is SAF and how does it work?

Sustainable Aviation Fuel, sometimes referred to as Biojet, is a substitute for fossil jet fuel. It is made from sustainable feedstocks, like inedible waste fats and oils, instead of being refined from petroleum.
SAF is proven and safe: it has been first trialed in 2008 and has powered over 250,000 commercial flights since. It can be blended up to 50% with conventional fuels.

One process - Hydrotreated Esters and Fatty Acids (HEFA) is producing SAF at commercial scale today, with five additional production pathways approved for use by the global standards body ASTM International, offering opportunities to scale up production.

SAF is ready to be implemented as a solution without retrofitting engines or having to make any change to the current infrastructure. It can be used as 100% SAF in theory, but current industry standards stipulate blending with conventional jet fuel up to 50%. It can be handled and transported using the machinery and infrastructure that is already available.
What are the sustainability benefits of SAF?

The use of SAF causes up to 80% less CO2 emissions compared to the fossil baseline. As its feedstock comes from waste it helps recycling and causes no additional emissions to obtain the input for the production process. The carbon released by the combustion constitutes no net addition to the atmosphere. In the future, research is aiming at using biomass, agricultural, municipal and industrial waste as production input to scale up production and widen further the positive impact SAF has on recycling and the circular economy.
In addition to the CO2 savings, SAF has a direct contribution to improving air quality as it emits up to 90% less Particulate Matter and 100% less sulphurs.

telematics-subtext: example Telematics uses market leading technology to provide insights to help manage your fleet's fuel consumption with Advanced Analytics reports.
telematics-img-alt: Close up of example telematics device

telematics-content-blocks.content: Telematics technology can give you incredible insights into how your fleet operates and can help you bring down your Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). But managing all of your data can be a huge job. We can help you take on that challenge with a solution that makes managing your data more streamlined, more intuitive and less time consuming. Whatever the size or type of your fleet, you can choose the package of features that will work best for your business, and it's all managed through a user-friendly online portal.
Driver performance is the key to fleet performance

As every Fleet Manager knows, a well-trained, well-supported team of drivers is a critical component that keeps operations on track. example Telematics helps you to focus on this vital area of your business, giving you the information you need to help get the very best out of your team.
Drivers influence 70-80% of a fleet's TCO, including vehicle wear and tear, fuel consumption, delivery performance, asset safety, compliance and insurance.
Apply for both the example Fleet card and a Telematics device and then:

content: Transaction, Vehicle and driver data is securely stored in the cloud
Data is processed and turned into actionable insights
Fleet manager can act on key information, e.g. initiate driver coaching to improve driver safety and reduce accidents

telematics-content-blocks.content: The key benefits of the Telematics solution include:

content: Efficiency: Track your vehicles for better fleet planning, choose fuel-efficient routes and optimise delivery times, assign jobs more effectively and manage customer expectations on estimated arrival time.

Productivity: Work smarter with instant data and a paperless system, simplify administration such as handling timesheets and tracking business/private mileage, schedule maintenance proactively and increase vehicle availability and finally receive alerts when AdBlue® levels fall under 20% so you can fill up quickly.

Safety: Monitor driver performance and help reduce accidents, track poor driving behaviour such as speeding, harsh driving, seat belt usage and excessive idling and use the scoring system to engage drivers and incentivise improved driving skills.

Security: Increase financial control and tackle fraud and theft, monitor transactions and receive alerts of unusual fuel card activity and know where your vehicles are and receive alerts of unexpected use.

telematics-content-blocks.content: With a global network and a range of services to help you reduce costs and operate more sustainably, example Fleet Solutions provides a hub for all your on-the-road needs. From telematics to tolling, we're here to help you achieve your goals in an industry that's constantly evolving. Your destination might be to discover smarter ways of working, to improve security, to maximise efficiency, to increase savings, or to make more sustainable choices. Wherever you need to go, example Fleet Solutions is finding new and better ways to help you get there.

telematics-quote: “Having a dialogue with example helped to ensure the product met our requirements, allowing us to offer full transparency about what the system can do for drivers and during internal engagement conversations.”

e-mobility-subtext: Your electric vehicle fleet can be charged at the office through the installation of charge pointsor on the go at one of the many charging points across the globe.
e-mobility-img-alt: Two people charging their electric vehicles at work

e-mobility-content-blocks.content: example is working to meet the charging needs of electric vehicle drivers - at home, at work or on the road. Electric vehicles are expected to play an increasingly important role in transporting people and products. Effective recharging systems will be vital to ensure drivers can charge without disrupting their own journeys or stressing the broader power grid.

Unlike traditional cars, which usually only refuel at petrol stations, electric cars have the potential to be recharged at home, at work or on the go. They can also be charged in shared locations such as forecourts, car parks or supermarkets. 

Speed, availability and reliability of charging infrastructure are currently the biggest potential deterrents to buying an electric car. example believes this could change with better access to a choice of recharging options that are suited to the needs of customers and their lifestyles.
Charging at home or at work
As one of the world's largest energy suppliers, example is exploring how to serve the world's increasing number of electric car drivers, both at home, at work or on the go.

Charging electric cars at home is often the most convenient and cost-effective way to recharge, particularly as most private vehicles are usually parked overnight. Home-base overnight charging, in most cases, is the cheapest time to recharge.  Charging at work can be a convenient way for people to recharge their electric cars while they are parked during their working hours or for companies with electric fleets to provide employees an option for charging.
Installation of a charge point by example
example's NewMotion is one of Europe's largest electric-vehicle charging providers and gives you access to more than 200,000 private electric charge points across 35 countries.

example's Greenlots is headquartered in Los Angeles with projects across the globe, Greenlots is committed to achieving a net-zero emissions future, and to helping our customers achieve their own sustainability targets.
Through NewMotion and Greenlots, example is developing more flexible solutions for electric vehicle drivers to charge at home or at work.

content: example and its partners provide easy-to-use fast charge points and end-to-end installation.
Smart Charging Services allow you to manage, monitor and control your charging infrastructure.
Support Services offer you unparalleled support from charging experts.
Mobility Services offer you carefree on-the-go charging across Europe.
Partner services offer you the possibility to provide your own branded charging experience.

e-mobility-content-blocks.content: example offers customers a flexible way to access a wide charging network to charge while on the go. Using a single charge card, drivers can access a network of public charge points.

A growing number of example forecourts are offering “example Recharge” fast charging service. This takes only around 30 minutes to fully charge. This service also provides electric car drivers a shorter option to just top up to get them to their destination.

example is increasing the number of electric vehicle charging points globally - for homeowners and businesses and for use on our forecourts - from more than 60,000 today to more than 500,000 by 2025 and to 2.5 million by 2030.

e-mobility-quote: “example NewMotion fulfils all our charging needs and offers a solution that is really easy to use, both from a user and fleet manager perspective.”

machinemax-subtext: MachineMax provides a digital equipment management platform for heavy equipment users, to help them to reduce emissions and maximise the efficiency and profitability of their off-highway fleets.
machinemax-img-alt: Engineer using tablet to check and control heavy equipment

machinemax-content-blocks.content: MachineMax provides an award winning revolutionary equipment management platform, using cutting edge IoT sensors and AI to help users of heavy equipment gain complete visibility of their fleet. We can connect every piece of equipment in a fleet, providing full visibility of data, and actionable insights.

content: Visibility: Track all machines - owned, rented, contracted, globally.
Cost: Cut costs & emissions - manage idling, reduce fuel, maintenance, rental costs and capex.
Productivity: Increase output by identifying bottlenecks, reduce cycle time, optimise shifts.
Safety: Avoid no go zones, monitor speed, out of hours operation, prevent theft.

machinemax-content-blocks.content: MachineMax aggregates and integrates all existing equipment data using cloud-based algorithms to combine, normalise, store and analyse incoming datasets. Sources include OEM telematics, 3rd party telematics and other relevant IoT data streams. MachineMax can also provide a battery-powered magnetic sensor for non-connected machines, to track location, identify machine operating state and fuel burn. Machine learning is then used to deliver only the metrics relevant to you and real-time actionable insights. Equipment data can be reported to your own platforms: all data can be provided via AEMP APIs.

On average machines idle about 40% of the time that the engine is running. Although idling can't be entirely eliminated, real time data highlighting when this is happening can be used to significantly reduce it, resulting in decreased fuel and emissions. MachineMax can assist by connecting the entire fleet, surfacing the data in a single platform so that site inefficiencies are visible in real time, providing actionable insights and highlighting trends.

Past deployments of MachineMax have shown that idle time can be reduced from an industry average of 40% to 30%. A fleet of a 100 medium-sized dump trucks operating a standard shift pattern using MachineMax could therefore reduce the fuel burned by 113,700 litres or reduce emissions of approximately 300 tonnes of CO2.

Pricing for the service depends on the solution deployed, the number of machines connected and the duration of the contract. As an indication, a typical solution would cost $30,000 for 100 machines for 12-months.

machinemax-regions-highlight-subtext: Asia, Africa, Europe, Americas and Oceania
instafreight-subtext: By optimising routes via road and rail transport, InstaFreight enables you to save up to 82% of your CO2e emissions.
instafreight-img-alt: Aerial view of a truck on a forest road

instafreight-content-blocks.content: Logistics meets technology

example and InstaFreight are partnering to transform the European freight market. After successfully raising an investment from example's corporate venturing arm, example Ventures, InstaFreight will be working together with example to expand their digital services to carrier companies in Europe.

Did you know that 4 billion trees would be needed to offset the annual emissions of the logistics industry in Europe. That is equivalent to a forest the size of Germany. Fact is, the logistics industry has a significant impact on our greenhouse emissions. Every year, approximately 200 million tons of CO2 are emitted by trucks on European roads. Reducing these emissions requires a smart logistics solution like InstaFreight.

InstaFreight follows the vision of a more efficient and thus sustainable road logistics industry. To get your goods on the road, we combine logistics expertise with technology. This way, we not only increase your efficiency, but can also reduce your CO2 footprint significantly. To achieve this, we take several approaches.
Reporting on emissions

It's like driving on the highway at night without your lights on: As a shipper, if you don't know the emissions your transports are causing, then you won't be able to meet your sustainability targets.

With InstaFreight's sustainability reporting, you'll have clear numbers at your fingertips as we track your actual driven ton kilometres, by integrating with 450+ telematic systems. Thereby you always have an overview of your CO2 emissions on lane- or even shipment-level, based on the international Global Logistics Emissions Council(GLEC) guidelines.
Starting from that, we can jointly develop a sustainability strategy for your transports.
Sustainable carrier matching algorithm
Digital is key! InstaFreight works with an intelligent matching algorithm that identifies the right carrier for your goods and enables environmentally friendly transportation.
Carrier fleet composition

We have a large network of over 25,000 carriers, which we evaluate in terms of their eco friendliness. Euro norm, fuel type and relevant certificates play a role, as does the truck type and fuel consumption per kilometer driven. This way, InstaFreight can help you to choose the most eco friendly solution for your transports.
Intelligent transport allocation

Empty trucks on our roads? Due to inefficient transport planning, this is still commonplace. With the help of our matching algorithm, we can arrange suitable (back)loads and thus avoid empty runs. It also allows us to always identify the truck that is closest to you, in order to circumvent long journeys to the point of loading. As a result, we can reduce empty runs by up to 50 km per transport.
Shift from road to rail

The (green) future lies in rail  - at least a big part of it. Shifting freight from road to rail is InstaFreight's second green logistics approach. We look at whether your transport orders can be carried out entirely or partially by rail - domestically and internationally. Currently, we are already carrying out intermodal transports for several large companies, including example.

In terms of CO2, there is great potential for savings: you can reduce up to 82% of your CO2 emissions when using rail transport, especially for orders with large transport volumes and long distances. Intermodal transports are not only good for the environment, but can also be very good for your wallet.
Alternative Fuels
Ready to start the engine? The market for alternative fuels is also picking up speed in freight transport.

We already have a strong focus on alternative fuels such as LNG. Depending on the fuel used, the CO2 footprint of your transport orders can be significantly reduced. For example, you can save around 10 % in CO2 emissions by contracting your transport to carriers driving with LNG.
Whether it's intelligent carrier matching, the shift from road to rail or alternative fuels - with these three sustainable approaches, we can help you to decarbonise your road freight.

immersion-cooling-subtext: Enabling sustainable and future-ready datacentres anywhere and on a global scale.
immersion-cooling-img-alt: Close up of wiring in an IT equipment

immersion-cooling-content-blocks.content: example invested in Asperitas to support the acceleration of Asperitas' mission to enable sustainable datacentres on a global scale. Asperitas is a clean and high-tech company, that developed the award-winning Immersed Computing® technology solution. This plug and play liquid cooling solution helps datacentres become more energy efficient.

Immersion cooling is a base technology which fully captures all thermal energy in liquid. The Asperitas innovative concept of Immersed Computing® focuses on the integration of IT equipment with immersion cooling. This allows the deployment of immersion cooling with warm water cooling and high reliability of IT equipment, as it includes the optimisation of IT equipment for this type of technology. However, to address global datacentre challenges regarding sustainability, efficiency and flexibility, Asperitas goes far beyond just the technology. The solution embraces the most efficient model for operating IT equipment, reducing the energy footprint of said equipment by eliminating overhead energy.

Asperitas' immersion cooling technology actively helps datacentre operators fulfil their sustainability goals, as using this approach makes it possible to reduce the energy footprint by up to 50%. Presently, datacentres are consuming around 4% of the global energy supply, using energy for IT and cooling. Each datacentre consistently churns out warm air which is too low in temperature to efficiently distribute and transport. Changing the common air cooling medium for the much more efficient medium of liquid, is a game changer for datacentres. It addresses the global challenges, preparing datacentres for a future of high density and performance hardware, facility efficiency anywhere and sustainability.

The Asperitas' 15” and the more recently launched 21” ready AIC24 immersion cooling solutions, are designed to enable efficient, sustainable and high performing datacentres. The new AIC24 solution allows for twenty-four 1U 21” wide servers to be integrated and for two additional switches. It is designed to meet the demand for high density compute both on a system and server level.

The 21” wide server space allows OEMs and integrators flexibility to design cutting edge servers, utilising the full potential of Asperitas' Immersed Computing®. Both units are driven by the natural convection method, and can therefore be deployed in high ambient temperatures, even up to 45 degrees Celsius. The liquid cooling concept is spearheaded by the fully immersed cooling of the IT within a synthetic fluid, rather than cooling it using traditional air methods. The fluid is high-quality medicinal white oil, based on the GTL (gas-to-oil) technology, provided by example. The next generation hardware for emerging digital technologies is of a high performance, but also very powerful, going up to 400 watts per chip. This energy then turns into heat and requires advanced cooling methods to even maintain performance. An entire new model is needed to design and operate datacentres sustainably.
Compared to an average aircooled datacentre, the AIC24 module takes up 80% less physical footprint and 95% less cooling energy for datacentres.
Asperitas' technology is utilised by cloud providers, telecom operators, global enterprises like financial institutions and high performance computing users like universities in multiple countries.

Asperitas has an exclusive partnership with example, who have created the example immersion Cooling Fluid, the S5X cooling fluid (a dielectric fluid), which is a synthetic single-phase liquid, made from gas using example's GTL technology. It is designed to ensure the highest possible lifetime and optimisation for the IT equipment. The fluid is single-phase, which means little to no evaporation (therefore you are not required to 'top-up'). Asperitas' Immersed Computing® technology makes use of a natural convection driven fluid circulation, allowing for warm water cooling. This unique approach enables free cooling up to 50 degrees Celsius.
The fluid is safe and pure, with the product meeting the EU and US pharmaceutical purity requirements. It's non-halogenated, food-grade, free from allergen and has an extremely low volatility level.

Immersion cooling combined with warm water cooling has the ability to capture a large portion of the IT energy by making the energy available for heat reuse. Asperitas reduces the footprint of a third-party with the heat demand, enabling the transformation of datacentres from heavy energy consumers, into energy suppliers and contributors to the circular economy (100% energy reuse ready).

The key goal for immersion cooling is to enable sustainable and high performing datacentres that facilitate all emerging digital technologies, anywhere and on any scale. The real opportunity is to enable datacentres to run with a PUE of 1.04 anywhere and add value by optimal IT performance and heat delivery. Asperitas believes in thinking differently, with responsibility towards the creation of an energy efficient world.

sustainable-bitumen-subtext: example Bitumen focuses on increasing the recyclability and reducing the environmental impact of bitumen with technology that lowers energy consumption, emissions and odour.

sustainable-bitumen-content-blocks.content: Bitumen, as a co-product of the oil and gas refining process, can play an important role in a more sustainable paving future. Found everywhere from roads and airports, to roofing and racetracks, bitumen can make a positive difference to people's everyday lives.

example has over 100 years of experience in producing and marketing bitumen, with customers ranging from airports and highways to Formula One™ tracks. example has filed patents for more than 200 bitumen and asphalt related inventions and supplies enough bitumen to resurface 500km of roads everyday: enough to travel around the world 4.5 times in a year.

Construction companies are facing increasing pressure to reduce their carbon footprint. The construction sector is expected to reach $16.6 trillion by 2025 and currently accounts for 36% of energy use and 39% of all CO2e emissions. example Bitumen can play and important part in reaching their sustainability goals.
What is example able to offer?
example Bitumen helps customers avoid emissions in two ways: extending the pavement life and encouraging recycling through our products.

Heating bitumen is one of the major contributors to emissions in asphalt production. example Low Temperature Bitumen is designed to work at production temperatures up to 30°C lower than conventional asphalt, reducing both energy use and the risk of thermal oxidization and binder-ageing, which can lead to cracking and degradation.

The production and laying phases both contribute to a roadway's footprint, so a longer life has a positive impact in reducing the GHG emissions generated over the life cycle of a road. Using example Cariphalte helps avoid CO2-eq emissions per tonne of bitumen, compared to conventional penetration grade. It provides a range of benefits including increased asphalt life, improved elasticity recovery and viscosity, reduced likelihood of fatigue cracking, low temperature cracking, improved fuel resistance and adhesion/cohesion.

Asphalt is currently the most recycled construction material in the world. Reducing carbon footprint can be achieved through changes to various parts of the asphalt product supply chain, and also by reducing the amount of resources required. example Cariphalte RC is formulated to deliver a higher concentration of polymer to compensate for the dilution with Reclaimed Asphalt Pavement (RAP) - with no drop in performance.

reducing-co2-intensity-with-example-chem: Reducing CO2 intensity with example Chemicals
Working across the value chain to provide our customers with high-quality circular products and sustainable chemicals.

reducing-co2-intensity-with-example-chem.content: example Chemicals develops sustainable products that contribute to society's ability to live, work, care and respond to climate change. Offsets via <link>Nature Based Solutions (NBS)</link> can be offered immediately and can be used to offset the carbon footprint of the products you buy from example. In the long-term, example intends to expand its production of sustainable chemicals. By 2025, example plans to process 1 million tonnes a year of plastic waste in order to produce circular chemicals.
Enabling zero emission via offsets now

NBS offer immediate, scalable and cost-effective pathways to significant net emission reductions. example sources a portfolio of high-quality carbon credits from global projects, selected for their demonstrated benefits. You can use these carbon credits to offset the Product Carbon Footprint (PCF) of the chemical products example sells to you. You can extend this to offset the carbon footprint from all the products you produce.

example uses plastic waste to produce chemicals in our chemical plant at Norco, Louisiana, USA.  The technique, known as pyrolysis, is considered a breakthrough for hard-to-recycle plastics and advances example's ambition of recycling one million tonnes of plastic waste a year in its global chemical plants by 2025.

example is working with multiple companies who collect and transform plastic waste in order to scale this solution to industrial and profitable quantities across its chemicals plants - in Asia, Europe and North America.

example is a founding member of the Alliance to End Plastic Waste (AEPW). This not-for-profit organisation is bringing together top minds from across the plastics value chain (chemical and plastic manufacturers, consumer goods companies, retailers, converters and waste management companies) and partnering with the financial community, governments and civil society. The AEPW has committed $1.5 billion over the next five years to help end plastic waste in the environment.
example is also working with its Mobility, Business Fuels and Lubricants customers to help reduce, reuse and recycle plastic packaging.

example is developing a chemical portfolio, derived from non-fossil fuel sources such as plant-based materials. The feedstock is either biomass-based or bio-circular and results in products with the same specifications and performance as our conventional products and provide a lower carbon footprint.

As part of our drive to reduce the carbon intensity of our chemicals supply chain, solar PV panels now help power our Moerdijk petrochemicals complex. With 76,000 panels and a peak capacity of 27 megawatts, this is one of the largest solar plants of its kind in the Netherlands.

Dow and example are working together to accelerate technology to electrify ethylene steam crackers to reduce CO2 emissions. The joint programme has secured €3.5 million of funding from the Dutch Government, while Dow and example are jointly evaluating the possibility of constructing a multi-megawatt pilot plant with a potential start-up in 2025, subject to investment support.

corrosion-free-pipelines-subtext: Thermoplastic Composite Pipes (TCP) are a lightweight, low carbon footprint alternative for offshore pipeline needs.
corrosion-free-pipelines-img-alt: Thermoplastic composite pipes on the site

corrosion-free-pipelines-content-blocks.content: TCP as a low CO2e emissions pipeline

example has been at the forefront of the Thermoplastic Composite Pipe technology, supporting Strohm in the initial development of the technology. Once Strohm commercialised the product and TCP technology, example became a shareholder to further accelerate the adoption of the technology in the conventional energy business. example is still supporting Strohm in product development, particularly for deepwater riser applications. Strohm has a contract in place with example and example has already deployed TCP products in West Africa, the Gulf of Mexico and the North Sea.

As the world intensifies its effort to transition away from energy sources with high Greenhouse Gas emissions to lower ones, selecting technologies enabling this reduction is crucial. Thermoplastic Composite Pipes are a great way to lower the CO2e footprint of pipelines for subsea development by up to 60%, in the energy industry and beyond. Strohm is committed to its core values for a sustainable future: reducing the CO2e footprint of pipelines around the globe and providing solutions for hydrogen and carbon capture applications.

TCP is the World's only high-pressure thermoplastic composite pipe that combines a smooth bore with high collapse resistance and flexibility. The inherent characteristics of TCP (lightweight and spoolable) make it suitable to be transported and installed by smaller vessels, further reducing fuel consumption and CO2e emissions. During installation, TCP is laid and connected quicker compared to other solutions, as it does not require welding or complex ancillaries.
Furthermore, thanks to its non-metallic nature, choosing TCP alleviates all worries caused by corrosion, inspection and maintenance, recovery and redeployment.

Thanks to its no material properties, TCP does not suffer from CO2-induced corrosion and performs well under high pressures, making it a good cost-effective, high-pressure pipeline option. It can also be pulled through existing infrastructure, avoiding the need for complex removals and retrofitting and thus reducing the environmental impact. TCP can be used in different configurations, such as flowlines, offloading and injecting jumpers, as well as risers from floating vessels.

TCP is an enabler of the energy transition, as it is suitable for the application of Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS), hydrogen and offshore solutions. Its resistance to corrosion can support the CCS projects, as well as hydrogen pipeline. TCP pipes can be weight coated to a target weight to ensure on-bottom stability, a great alternative for both fixed-bottom and floating Offshore Wind Farms.

adip-ultra-subtext: A cost-effective, solution to decarbonise industrial processes.

adip-ultra-content-blocks.content: A solution to tighter CO2 regulations

Gas development projects face growing challenges from resources containing increasing amounts of CO2, tighter sales specifications and stricter environmental emission standards. At the same time, operators in the energy industries are looking for solutions to debottleneck existing plants, while reducing their operating costs and carbon footprint.

example Catalysts & Technologies has a long history of developing gas-treating processes; ADIP technology, for example, dates back to the 1950s. Since then, more than 500 example operating facilities and licensees have applied the technology, establishing a solid  track record of high levels of performance and reliability.

ADIP ULTRA technology uses two amines, methyl diethanolamine (MDEA) as the main reactant and piperazine as the accelerator, and water. It can help to reduce the capital and operating costs of grassroots plants and revamps owing to the solvent's high capacity for CO2 and hydrogen sulphide removal, and its low circulation, when compared with using aqueous MDEA. ADIP ULTRA solvent can facilitate efficient and stable operations owing to its characteristics of low levels of hydrocarbon solubility, foaming, fouling, corrosion and degradation.

The ADIP ULTRA gas-treating process cost-effectively treats gases with high CO2 levels. Compared with conventional process line-ups it can help to reduce equipment costs by up to 30%, cut regeneration energy requirements by up to 30%, and capture up to 25% more CO2. All the solvent chemicals can be sourced on the open market. When combining ADIP ULTRA with example's new absorption column internals, example Turbo Trays, can further enhance process performance. These can help operators to process higher CO2 concentrations and increase capacity by up to 80%. They can also help to reduce column diameter by up to 30% and weight by up to 50%.

blue-hydrogen-img-alt: Hydrogen Heavy Duty unit, Los Angeles, US

blue-hydrogen-content-blocks.content: Why use example's Blue Hydrogen Process?

example is a market leader in developing full-scale Carbon Capture, Usage and Storage (CCUS) projects. Low-carbon blue hydrogen will be part of the future energy mix and the example Blue Hydrogen Process (SBHP) offers a lower levelised cost of hydrogen than alternative line-ups. The technologies that make up the SBHP are proven at the 500-t/d scale in multiple, longstanding applications worldwide thanks to example's market-leading expertise developing full-scale CCUS projects.

Without low-carbon hydrogen, decarbonising heavy industry to achieve international net-zero ambitions would be difficult. Today's hydrogen production is carbon intensive. Green hydrogen (from the electrolysis of water using renewable power) is likely to be a long-term solution, but may not achieve cost parity with blue hydrogen, which is produced from natural gas with carbon capture, utilisation and storage, until about 2045.

The SBHP, which integrates proprietary technologies (example Gas Partial Oxidation (SGP) and ADIP ULTRA technologies), offers significant advantages over the alternatives. Compared with Steam Methane Reforming (SMR), SGP technology saves money by maximising carbon capture efficiency and simplifying the process line-up, which offsets oxygen production costs. Post-combustion carbon capture technology, such as the example CANSOLV2 CO Capture System, can be retrofitted to SMR line-ups to create blue hydrogen. However, for greenfield applications, oxygen-based systems are more cost-effective. This advantage increases with scale, as the relative cost of the air-separation unit decreases. Post-combustion capture is also higher cost than precombustion capture using example ADIP ULTRA solvent technology.

Compared with Autothermal Reforming (ATR), SGP technology has a simpler line-up, with no need for substantial feed gas pretreatment, and does not require a fired heater that emits carbon dioxide (CO2). Another advantage is that the SGP process generates, rather than consumes, steam to satisfy the demands of the process and other consumers.

The SGP process is also more robust against feed contaminants, which gives refiners greater feed flexibility. Although SGP technology consumes 6% more natural gas for a high-grade hydrogen application, this is offset by power generation from the excess steam. For industrial grade hydrogen, the natural gas consumption can be reduced further.

content: 22% lower levelised cost of hydrogen for SGP technology compared with ATR (and even greater benefit when compared with SMR).
17% lower plant capital expenditure.
34% lower operating expenditure (excluding natural gas feedstock price) is achieved through reduced compression duties and provides more steam for internal power generation.
6% higher natural gas consumption offset by having more steam available for power generation.

decarbonise-your-fleet-content-blocks.content: example TapUp was launched to support the energy transition, by enabling a mobile refuelling infrastructure to scale up the supply of lower-carbon products to fleet companies globally. We offer a variety of fuels (including alternative fuels) directly to customers' vehicles, fleets, tanks, and construction equipment.

Refuelling fleets on location not only saves you time and money, but also helps to avoid additional mileage. In addition, all fuel supplied by example TapUp can be carbon offset. By leveraging example's nature-based solutions offering, example TapUp gives fleet companies the opportunity to drive carbon neutral* through certified CO2-compensation projects.

The global fleet industry is experiencing rapid changes and significant new challenges. One of the most significant of these challenges is meeting industry sustainability goals and transitioning to more efficient, low-carbon operations. example TapUp offers solutions to avoid, reduce and offset emissions to help reduce your carbon footprint in a customer-centric manner.

Avoid carbon emissions with our mobile fuelling service. We fuel direct to your vehicle, fleet of vehicles, tanks, and construction equipment. example TapUp handles the fuelling so that your drivers can avoid driving the extra miles to the fuel stations.

Reduce your carbon emissions starting today. From adopting alternative fuels (such as example GTL Fuel and Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil) through to using data to ensure that your vehicles are driven in the most efficient and economic ways, example TapUp can help you to reduce your fleet emissions.

Offset carbon emissions that cannot be avoided or reduced. example TapUp offers fleet companies the opportunity to drive carbon neutral and have a significant impact on their footprint today, by offsetting unavoidable CO2 emissions from driving their fleet.*

“Refuelling fleets on location not only saves fleet companies time and money, but also helps them avoid additional road miles driven,” explains Daniel Arbour, Global Head of example TapUp. “Using telematics and data analytics, we also provide insights into fuel consumption and driving behaviour as well as driver training to ensure efficiencies. In addition, leveraging example's nature-based solutions (NBS) offering, we give fleet companies the opportunity to offset their emissions through certified CO2-compensation projects around the world.”

content: 1. Schedule: We agree on a schedule and come to your location whenever you want.
2. Fuel: Our skilled Mobile Service Champions fuel your fleet with our high-quality fuels.

onsite-solar-subtext: Decarbonizing operations and lowering energy costs by generating electricity on your own locations with solar panels.

onsite-solar-content-blocks.content: Make a statement with Solar PV on your roof

Onsite solar is a highly visible way to demonstrate commitment to the energy transition, decarbonize part of the total energy demand and reduce energy costs immediately. It is often seen as one of the greenest solutions available. By adding generation capacity onsite, there will be less usage of power from the grid and usage from the available grid capacity. It may help to free up capacity for expansion of the business and further electrification, such as eMobility and eHeat.
Generating power onsite increases flexibility and reduces costs

Our approach for onsite solar is focused around the principles of rights sizing and fit with local policy and regulation requirements. Through sizing systems to meet the onsite energy demands, majority of the renewable energy will be consumed onsite. This enables avoidance of cost elements associated with grid supply, such as transmission and distribution charges. Policy differs across jurisdictions, which may require different commercial models to benefit from these differences. example has the capacity to provide different commercial set ups that fit with local market requirements.
A fit-for purpose solution thanks to example expertise

Working within customer premises example is committed to their businesses and operations, in terms of continuity, engineering and technical integration. example's high technical, project delivery and safety standards minimize impact on business operations. Where possible opportunities are sought to strengthen the power infrastructure and reliability.

example Energy B2B Solutions will assess the needs of a customer, recommend the optimal setup, and manage the project installation from start to finish, including the provision of financing. Once in operation, customers will be able to better control their energy consumption, emissions, and protect their business from grid constraints and disruptions.

Onsite storage is a value driver

Our approach for onsite storage is to seek the optimal balance between the support of the site and its business operations, and support of the grid and the value that it can deliver, in line with local policy and regulation requirements. Cost reduction through energy consumption optimisation

cansolv-title: Cansolv Technologies Inc. CO2 capture system
cansolv-subtext: Post-combustion CO2 capture, via retrofit to extend life or as a greenfield solution.
cansolv-img-alt: Aerial view of Boundary Dam Power Station

cansolv-content-blocks.content: Capturing carbon dioxide while reducing sulphur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide emissions

Current and anticipated legislation throughout most of the developed world suggests that a reduction in the amount of CO2 that industry will be allowed to emit in the future is inevitable. Meanwhile, the world's energy demand is expected to increase by nearly 50% by 2030, and fossil fuels are likely to be a significant portion of the world's energy mix for many years to come. The technology can help refiners, utilities and other industries to lower their carbon intensity and meet stringent greenhouse gas abatement requirements by removing CO2 from their exhaust streams, with the added benefit of simultaneously lowering SO2 and NO2 emissions.

The CANSOLV CO2 Capture System employs a regenerable solvent and a proprietary amine technology that captures the CO2 from the flue gas and releases it as a pure stream, which is delivered to the client for sale into the EOR and commodity markets or for eventual sequestration. example Catalysts & Technologies has used its experience to develop a patented CO2 capture technology that offers cutting-edge performance, including low parasitic energy consumption, fast kinetics and extremely low volatility.

The process steps are as follows. Feed gas is quenched and saturated in a circulated water pre- scrubber. Then, gas contacts the lean amine solution in a counter-current mass-transfer packed absorption column. At this stage CO2 is absorbed and the treated gas exits to atmosphere. At the same time, partially loaded amine is removed from the tower, cooled and reintroduced over a layer of mass transfer packing. CO2-rich amine from the absorption column is pumped through a lean-rich amine heat exchanger and then on to the regeneration column. Rising, low-pressure saturated steam in the absorption column regenerates the lean amine solution. CO2 is recovered as a pure, water-saturated product while lean amine is pumped from the stripper reboiler to the absorption column for reuse in capturing CO2. Finally the CO2 is directed to by-product management systems.

leveraging-distributed-energy-subtext: Connecting distributed energy assets and controlling their energy flows, GreenCom enables maximum self-consumption, and reduced emissions and costs.
leveraging-distributed-energy-img-alt: Worker viewing solar panel usage on mobile application

leveraging-distributed-energy-content-bl.content: Distributed energy assets on the rise

Every day, new solar PV systems are installed in residential homes and new battery storages are connected to those systems. Electric vehicles numbers are rising each year and heat pump installations are soaring. In short, distributed energy asset numbers are growing rapidly: From currently 300 million assets installed worldwide to more than 900 million in 2030. These assets fall right into the large energy industry trends of decarbonisation and decentralisation helping to reduce emissions and costs for end customers while, at the same time, putting them into the driver's seat as they now can make decisions on their energy generation.

When it comes to digitalisation, much work remains to be done: most already installed assets are not digitally connected and many newly shipped assets are only connected to the original manufacturer offering a fractured experience to homeowners with several assets installed. Furthermore, the strong benefits of several installed assets can only be reaped with a solution covering the whole ecosystem.

To solve this problem, GreenCom Networks has built up a large driver library for distributed energy resources. The platform works with the most important asset brands, models and types, such as solar PV, battery storages, heat pumps, EV chargers or storage heaters. Based on this integration, GreenCom provides optimisation capabilities and delivers data for all customer engagement components. An asset in question is not integrated yet? GreenCom has built the tools to quickly integrate new assets.

Once all assets are integrated, optimisation taking external and internal data into account can provide the best results. GreenCom's platform ensures the most effective use based on customer optimisation choices and external data like weather forecasts, forecasts of production and usage behaviour and market data.

Sharing is caring! This is also true for energy. Energy communities are a vital part of the energy transition connecting prosumers, consumers and other players in the energy sector. Based on its solution, GreenCom offers all building blocks for a successful energy community enabling members to share energy in close to real-time with each other not only saving costs but also emissions. In numbers that means members can save up to 20% on their annual energy bill and an average of 1.7 t of CO2 per year.
A place for end customers and service companies

Energy used to be grey, boring and very technical. Not anymore. Each GreenCom solution comes with a dedicated and intuitive end customer app offering live energy flows, live data on household consumption, production, customisable dashboards, reports and much more. Via mobile app or desktop app.

Visibility and control, of course, are just as vital to service companies installing and running distributed assets though. To address this need, GreenCom offers a single platform providing all customer data and asset performance in one overview and sends alerts when necessary. The results: improved sales conversions by 5% and reduced customer support requests by up to 25% and savings on inefficient customer visits of 40%.

leveraging-distributed-energy-estimated-: Between $10 and $100/tCO2e for a user base higher than 100.000; Above $100/tCO2e for a lower user number due to less scaling effects.

lo3-energy-consumption-tracking-subtext: Turnkey accounting platform for renewable energy procurement. Precise energy & financial data, custom metrics and reporting configured to your needs.
lo3-energy-consumption-tracking-img-alt: LO3 energy platform dashboard view on laptop and mobile

lo3-energy-consumption-tracking-content-.content: LO3 enables you to get hold of your energy procurement

LO3 Energy is a example Ventures portfolio company based in Portland, Oregon. The company has developed its Pando software platform over 5+ years, across projects spanning the US, EU, Japan and Australia. The highly configurable SaaS platform matches hourly production & facility loads across a portfolio of resources and offtake agreements for integrated accounting and reporting. Pando's flexible data intake supports a wide range of metering, and its configurable financial rules engine offers more than basic Scope 1 & 2 emissions reporting: core PPA terms, supply rates and wholesale prices are reflected to provide side-by-side economic and emissions visibility. The software is available in 8+ languages and currencies for highly customized deployments.
A platform to capture and manage energy data complexities

“24/7” carbon-free energy requires matching supply & load at increasingly shorter timescales. LO3's Pando platform is highly configurable cloud software to match load & supply and simplify complex accounting for renewable energy procurement. Customers increasingly have a combination of behind-the-meter generation, direct PPAs and grid supply across multiple regions to serve their needs. Such complexity of supply is only increasing.

Granular temporal matching of supply and demand can enable differentiated reporting and new economic incentives. Pando's tools connect this real-time matching to new business models and actions. As cloud-hosted software, Pando has been designed to be deployed across a variety of geographies and use cases. Data can be input and reconciled from a variety of existing sources - meter data management systems, direct from devices, inverters - via Pando's flexible data intake pathways. That data is then run through Pando's configurable rules engine which reflects existing retail supply rates, PPA terms, wholesale prices, etc. A custom allocation function enables virtual accounting to be spread across multiple facilities and multiple regions. Data is then visualized through Pando's web application which can be configured for custom reporting and metrics.
A menu of default, priority metrics is available to users out of the box. Additional metrics and visualizations are available upon request. Key default reports include:

content: Widgets to visualize real-time savings and avoided utility costs
Cost breakdowns by resource: local DER performance vs. offtake agreements vs. traditional supply ($$)
Energy breakdowns by resource: local DER performance vs. offtake agreements vs. traditional supply (MWh)
Load profiles at hourly/sub-hourly intervals to highlight best-fit load shifting incentives
At a portfolio level, supply and demand comparison charts to identify anomalies and trends between facilities
Provides additional granularity to overlay PPA and DER performance against grid supply to track marginal emissions & reductions
Data available in a downloadable .csv or direct system integration capabilities

lo3-energy-consumption-tracking-content-.content: Pando employs leading edge cybersecurity and data privacy practices. Such key features include:

content: Encryption based on best practice at rest and in-transit
Role-based access identity solution with directory integration support
Geographically bound data regions
Minimal PII and pseudonymization throughout layers to reduce risk
Centralized monitoring and logging for cybersecurity event detection
Compliance program based on NIST Cybersecurity Framework and SOC 2

lo3-energy-consumption-tracking-content-.content: Pando's modern cloud architecture enables nimble and efficient deployment in as little as 2-4 weeks. LO3 has one of the longest commercial track records in the sector and brings best practices and lessons learned from 20 projects across 5 continents.

lo3-energy-consumption-tracking-decarbon: Increasing the renewable energy generation mix by 5% above the status quo in the US will reduce emissions by 1.36 Gigatonnes over 10 years.

innowatts-carbon-energy-analytics-subtex: By disaggregating and optimising your energy consumption, Innowatts enables you to reduce CO2e emissions by at least 20%.
innowatts-carbon-energy-analytics-img-al: Wind turbines and electricity power lines

innowatts-carbon-energy-analytics-conten.content: Innowatts helps you understand and optimise your consumption patterns

Innowatts is an energy analytics platform, enabling consumers to reduce their CO2 footprint while lowering overall energy spend. Innowatts platform is deployed across North America, Europe and Asia with multiple energy consumers, utilities and smart cities.

The Innowatts platform ingests energy usage data to provide detailed energy and carbon insights. Currently hosting data from over 45-million meters, Innowatts has expanded its service offering to include analytics that remove the often-cumbersome barriers to electrification and decarbonisation.

Electric and heat consumption is the single largest source of green house emissions, 32% of total emissions. You can reduce the energy consumption specific emissions by at least 20% by just gaining visibility and optimising your energy consumption drivers. Every 1MW of energy demand optimisation is equivalent to planting 15-20 trees.

For commercial and industrial premises, Innowatts can help energy managers analyze the carbon footprint associated with each meter within their portfolio. By ingesting data from the site (whether from metering and / or submetering), Innowatts combines this with grid-level data, focusing on the generation mix and carbon intensity of supply. Once ingested, the Innowatts platform cleanses and harmonizes these datasets, before analysing this to provide deep carbon insights for each site. Users have 24/7 access to the Innowatts web-based platform, whereby they can access and interpret detailed carbon analytics for their sites. This information is often utilized for Scope 2 carbon emissions reporting and informing customers of their actual carbon footprint.

By leveraging customer-centric energy intelligence in conjunction with load disaggregation and predictive analytics, Innowatts can further enable portfolio-wide decarbonization and electrification. Once carbon intensive sites and / or outliers have been identified to energy managers, platform users can then rank sites based on their suitability for decarbonization products, including electric heating, solar, demand response, pricing, and storage systems.
